data.event: Prior to the arrival of the Europeans, Kabaka Muteesa I Mukaabya Walugembe Kayiira, the 30th Kabaka of the Kingdom of Buganda, who reigned from 1856 until 1884, maintained a palace on the hill.
Prior to the arrival of the Europeans, Kabaka Muteesa I Mukaabya Walugembe Kayiira, the 30th Kabaka of the Kingdom of Buganda, who reigned from 1856 until 1884, maintained a palace on the hill.

event.title: met Kabaka Walugembe Muteesa I in 1862

data.event: It was at this palace that British explorer John Hanning Speke met Kabaka Walugembe Muteesa I in 1862.
Muteesa detained Speke for some months before finally releasing him in his quest to look for the source of the Nile River.

event.title: ’s village in Kyaggwe County, which is now

data.event: He left Banda and built another palace at Nabulagala which he later called Kasubi, named after his mother’s village in Kyaggwe County, which is now known as Mukono District.

event.title: Today, the great, great grandson of Muteesa I, Kabaka Ronald Muwenda Mutebi II, the reigning Buganda monarch, maintains

data.event: Today, the great, great grandson of Muteesa I, Kabaka Ronald Muwenda Mutebi II, the reigning Buganda monarch, maintains a palace on the hill with the entrance facing west, as is the tradition.
